17656.text: §¶The vision concerning Judah and Jerusalem that Isaiah son of Amoz saw during the reigns of Uzziah, Jotham, Ahaz and Hezekiah, kings of Judah.

17657.text: §¶Hear me, you heavens! Listen, earth!/_For the Lord has spoken:/“I reared children and brought them up,/_but they have rebelled against me.

17658.text: /The ox knows its master,/_the donkey its owner’s manger,/but Israel does not know,/_my people do not understand.”

17659.text: ¶Woe to the sinful nation,/_a people whose guilt is great,/a brood of evildoers,/_children given to corruption!/They have forsaken the Lord;/_they have spurned the Holy One of Israel/_and turned their backs on him.

17660.text: ¶Why should you be beaten anymore?/_Why do you persist in rebellion?/Your whole head is injured,/_your whole heart afflicted.

17661.text: /From the sole of your foot to the top of your head/_there is no soundness—/only wounds and welts/_and open sores,/not cleansed or bandaged/_or soothed with olive oil.

17662.text: ¶Your country is desolate,/_your cities burned with fire;/your fields are being stripped by foreigners/_right before you,/_laid waste as when overthrown by strangers.

17663.text: /Daughter Zion is left/_like a shelter in a vineyard,/like a hut in a cucumber field,/_like a city under siege.

17664.text: /Unless the Lord Almighty/_had left us some survivors,/we would have become like Sodom,/_we would have been like Gomorrah.

17665.text: ¶Hear the word of the Lord,/_you rulers of Sodom;/listen to the instruction of our God,/_you people of Gomorrah!

17666.text: /“The multitude of your sacrifices—/_what are they to me?” says the Lord./“I have more than enough of burnt offerings,/_of rams and the fat of fattened animals;/I have no pleasure/_in the blood of bulls and lambs and goats.

17667.text: /When you come to appear before me,/_who has asked this of you,/_this trampling of my courts?

17668.text: /Stop bringing meaningless offerings!/_Your incense is detestable to me./New Moons, Sabbaths and convocations—/_I cannot bear your worthless assemblies.

17669.text: /Your New Moon feasts and your appointed festivals/_I hate with all my being./They have become a burden to me;/_I am weary of bearing them.

17670.text: /When you spread out your hands in prayer,/_I hide my eyes from you;/even when you offer many prayers,/_I am not listening.¶Your hands are full of blood!

17671.text: ¶Wash and make yourselves clean./_Take your evil deeds out of my sight;/_stop doing wrong.

17672.text: /Learn to do right; seek justice./_Defend the oppressed./Take up the cause of the fatherless;/_plead the case of the widow.

17673.text: ¶“Come now, let us settle the matter,”/_says the Lord./“Though your sins are like scarlet,/_they shall be as white as snow;/though they are red as crimson,/_they shall be like wool.

17674.text: /If you are willing and obedient,/_you will eat the good things of the land;

17675.text: /but if you resist and rebel,/_you will be devoured by the sword.”/For the mouth of the Lord has spoken.

17676.text: ¶See how the faithful city/_has become a prostitute!/She once was full of justice;/_righteousness used to dwell in her—/_but now murderers!

17677.text: /Your silver has become dross,/_your choice wine is diluted with water.

17678.text: /Your rulers are rebels,/_partners with thieves;/they all love bribes/_and chase after gifts./They do not defend the cause of the fatherless;/_the widow’s case does not come before them.

17679.text: ¶Therefore the Lord, the Lord Almighty,/_the Mighty One of Israel, declares:/“Ah! I will vent my wrath on my foes/_and avenge myself on my enemies.

17680.text: /I will turn my hand against you;/_I will thoroughly purge away your dross/_and remove all your impurities.

17681.text: /I will restore your leaders as in days of old,/_your rulers as at the beginning./Afterward you will be called/_the City of Righteousness,/_the Faithful City.”

17682.text: ¶Zion will be delivered with justice,/_her penitent ones with righteousness.

17683.text: /But rebels and sinners will both be broken,/_and those who forsake the Lord will perish.

17684.text: ¶“You will be ashamed because of the sacred oaks/_in which you have delighted;/you will be disgraced because of the gardens/_that you have chosen.

17685.text: /You will be like an oak with fading leaves,/_like a garden without water.

17686.text: /The mighty man will become tinder/_and his work a spark;/both will burn together,/_with no one to quench the fire.”

17687.text: §¶This is what Isaiah son of Amoz saw concerning Judah and Jerusalem:

17688.text: ¶In the last days¶▼the mountain of the Lord’s temple will be established/_as the highest of the mountains;/it will be exalted above the hills,/_and all nations will stream to it.

17689.text: ¶Many peoples will come and say,¶▼“Come, let us go up to the mountain of the Lord,/_to the temple of the God of Jacob./He will teach us his ways,/_so that we may walk in his paths.”/The law will go out from Zion,/_the word of the Lord from Jerusalem.

17690.text: /He will judge between the nations/_and will settle disputes for many peoples./They will beat their swords into plowshares/_and their spears into pruning hooks./Nation will not take up sword against nation,/_nor will they train for war anymore.

17691.text: ¶Come, descendants of Jacob,/_let us walk in the light of the Lord.

17692.text: §¶You, Lord, have abandoned your people,/_the descendants of Jacob./They are full of superstitions from the East;/_they practice divination like the Philistines/_and embrace pagan customs.

17693.text: /Their land is full of silver and gold;/_there is no end to their treasures./Their land is full of horses;/_there is no end to their chariots.

17694.text: /Their land is full of idols;/_they bow down to the work of their hands,/_to what their fingers have made.

17695.text: /So people will be brought low/_and everyone humbled—/_do not forgive them.

17696.text: ¶Go into the rocks, hide in the ground/_from the fearful presence of the Lord/_and the splendor of his majesty!

17697.text: /The eyes of the arrogant will be humbled/_and human pride brought low;/the Lord alone will be exalted in that day.

17698.text: ¶The Lord Almighty has a day in store/_for all the proud and lofty,/for all that is exalted/_(and they will be humbled),

17699.text: /for all the cedars of Lebanon, tall and lofty,/_and all the oaks of Bashan,

17700.text: /for all the towering mountains/_and all the high hills,

17701.text: /for every lofty tower/_and every fortified wall,

17702.text: /for every trading ship/_and every stately vessel.

17703.text: /The arrogance of man will be brought low/_and human pride humbled;/the Lord alone will be exalted in that day,

17705.text: ¶People will flee to caves in the rocks/_and to holes in the ground/from the fearful presence of the Lord/_and the splendor of his majesty,/_when he rises to shake the earth.

17706.text: /In that day people will throw away/_to the moles and bats/their idols of silver and idols of gold,/_which they made to worship.

17707.text: /They will flee to caverns in the rocks/_and to the overhanging crags/from the fearful presence of the Lord/_and the splendor of his majesty,/_when he rises to shake the earth.

17708.text: ¶Stop trusting in mere humans,/_who have but a breath in their nostrils./_Why hold them in esteem?

17709.text: §¶See now, the Lord,/_the Lord Almighty,/is about to take from Jerusalem and Judah/_both supply and support:/all supplies of food and all supplies of water,

17710.text: /_the hero and the warrior,/the judge and the prophet,/_the diviner and the elder,

17711.text: /the captain of fifty and the man of rank,/_the counselor, skilled craftsman and clever enchanter.

17712.text: ¶“I will make mere youths their officials;/_children will rule over them.”

17713.text: ¶People will oppress each other—/_man against man, neighbor against neighbor./The young will rise up against the old,/_the nobody against the honored.

17714.text: ¶A man will seize one of his brothers/_in his father’s house, and say,/“You have a cloak, you be our leader;/_take charge of this heap of ruins!”

17715.text: /But in that day he will cry out,/_“I have no remedy./I have no food or clothing in my house;/_do not make me the leader of the people.”

17716.text: ¶Jerusalem staggers,/_Judah is falling;/their words and deeds are against the Lord,/_defying his glorious presence.

17717.text: /The look on their faces testifies against them;/_they parade their sin like Sodom;/_they do not hide it./Woe to them!/_They have brought disaster upon themselves.

17718.text: ¶Tell the righteous it will be well with them,/_for they will enjoy the fruit of their deeds.

17719.text: /Woe to the wicked!/_Disaster is upon them!/They will be paid back/_for what their hands have done.

17720.text: ¶Youths oppress my people,/_women rule over them./My people, your guides lead you astray;/_they turn you from the path.

17721.text: ¶The Lord takes his place in court;/_he rises to judge the people.

17722.text: /The Lord enters into judgment/_against the elders and leaders of his people:/“It is you who have ruined my vineyard;/_the plunder from the poor is in your houses.

17723.text: /What do you mean by crushing my people/_and grinding the faces of the poor?”/declares the Lord, the Lord Almighty.

17724.text: ¶The Lord says,/_“The women of Zion are haughty,/walking along with outstretched necks,/_flirting with their eyes,/strutting along with swaying hips,/_with ornaments jingling on their ankles.

17725.text: /Therefore the Lord will bring sores on the heads of the women of Zion;/_the Lord will make their scalps bald.”

17726.text: ¶In that day the Lord will snatch away their finery: the bangles and headbands and crescent necklaces,

17727.text: the earrings and bracelets and veils,

17728.text: the headdresses and anklets and sashes, the perfume bottles and charms,

17729.text: the signet rings and nose rings,

17730.text: the fine robes and the capes and cloaks, the purses

17731.text: and mirrors, and the linen garments and tiaras and shawls.

17732.text: ¶Instead of fragrance there will be a stench;/_instead of a sash, a rope;/instead of well‐dressed hair, baldness;/_instead of fine clothing, sackcloth;/_instead of beauty, branding.

17733.text: /Your men will fall by the sword,/_your warriors in battle.

17734.text: /The gates of Zion will lament and mourn;/_destitute, she will sit on the ground.

17735.text: ¶In that day seven women/_will take hold of one man/and say, “We will eat our own food/_and provide our own clothes;/only let us be called by your name./_Take away our disgrace!”

17736.text: §¶In that day the Branch of the Lord will be beautiful and glorious, and the fruit of the land will be the pride and glory of the survivors in Israel.

17737.text: Those who are left in Zion, who remain in Jerusalem, will be called holy, all who are recorded among the living in Jerusalem.

17738.text: The Lord will wash away the filth of the women of Zion; he will cleanse the bloodstains from Jerusalem by a spirit of judgment and a spirit of fire.

17739.text: Then the Lord will create over all of Mount Zion and over those who assemble there a cloud of smoke by day and a glow of flaming fire by night; over everything the glory will be a canopy.

17740.text: It will be a shelter and shade from the heat of the day, and a refuge and hiding place from the storm and rain.

17741.text: §¶I will sing for the one I love/_a song about his vineyard:/My loved one had a vineyard/_on a fertile hillside.

17742.text: /He dug it up and cleared it of stones/_and planted it with the choicest vines./He built a watchtower in it/_and cut out a winepress as well./Then he looked for a crop of good grapes,/_but it yielded only bad fruit.

17743.text: ¶“Now you dwellers in Jerusalem and people of Judah,/_judge between me and my vineyard.

17744.text: /What more could have been done for my vineyard/_than I have done for it?/When I looked for good grapes,/_why did it yield only bad?

17745.text: /Now I will tell you/_what I am going to do to my vineyard:/I will take away its hedge,/_and it will be destroyed;/I will break down its wall,/_and it will be trampled.

17746.text: /I will make it a wasteland,/_neither pruned nor cultivated,/_and briers and thorns will grow there./I will command the clouds/_not to rain on it.”

17747.text: ¶The vineyard of the Lord Almighty/_is the nation of Israel,/and the people of Judah/_are the vines he delighted in./And he looked for justice, but saw bloodshed;/_for righteousness, but heard cries of distress.

17748.text: §¶Woe to you who add house to house/_and join field to field/till no space is left/_and you live alone in the land.

17749.text: ¶The Lord Almighty has declared in my hearing:¶▼“Surely the great houses will become desolate,/_the fine mansions left without occupants.

17750.text: /A ten‐acre vineyard will produce only a bath of wine;/_a homer of seed will yield only an ephah of grain.”

17751.text: ¶Woe to those who rise early in the morning/_to run after their drinks,/who stay up late at night/_till they are inflamed with wine.

17752.text: /They have harps and lyres at their banquets,/_pipes and timbrels and wine,/but they have no regard for the deeds of the Lord,/_no respect for the work of his hands.

17753.text: /Therefore my people will go into exile/_for lack of understanding;/those of high rank will die of hunger/_and the common people will be parched with thirst.

17754.text: /Therefore Death expands its jaws,/_opening wide its mouth;/into it will descend their nobles and masses/_with all their brawlers and revelers.

17755.text: /So people will be brought low/_and everyone humbled,/_the eyes of the arrogant humbled.

17756.text: /But the Lord Almighty will be exalted by his justice,/_and the holy God will be proved holy by his righteous acts.

17757.text: /Then sheep will graze as in their own pasture;/_lambs will feed among the ruins of the rich.

17758.text: ¶Woe to those who draw sin along with cords of deceit,/_and wickedness as with cart ropes,

17759.text: /to those who say, “Let God hurry;/_let him hasten his work/_so we may see it./The plan of the Holy One of Israel—/_let it approach, let it come into view,/_so we may know it.”

17760.text: ¶Woe to those who call evil good/_and good evil,/who put darkness for light/_and light for darkness,/who put bitter for sweet/_and sweet for bitter.

17761.text: ¶Woe to those who are wise in their own eyes/_and clever in their own sight.

17762.text: ¶Woe to those who are heroes at drinking wine/_and champions at mixing drinks,

17763.text: /who acquit the guilty for a bribe,/_but deny justice to the innocent.

17764.text: /Therefore, as tongues of fire lick up straw/_and as dry grass sinks down in the flames,/so their roots will decay/_and their flowers blow away like dust;/for they have rejected the law of the Lord Almighty/_and spurned the word of the Holy One of Israel.

17765.text: /Therefore the Lord’s anger burns against his people;/_his hand is raised and he strikes them down./The mountains shake,/_and the dead bodies are like refuse in the streets.¶Yet for all this, his anger is not turned away,/_his hand is still upraised.

17766.text: ¶He lifts up a banner for the distant nations,/_he whistles for those at the ends of the earth./Here they come,/_swiftly and speedily!

17767.text: /Not one of them grows tired or stumbles,/_not one slumbers or sleeps;/not a belt is loosened at the waist,/_not a sandal strap is broken.

17768.text: /Their arrows are sharp,/_all their bows are strung;/their horses’ hooves seem like flint,/_their chariot wheels like a whirlwind.

17769.text: /Their roar is like that of the lion,/_they roar like young lions;/they growl as they seize their prey/_and carry it off with no one to rescue.

17770.text: /In that day they will roar over it/_like the roaring of the sea./And if one looks at the land,/_there is only darkness and distress;/_even the sun will be darkened by clouds.

17771.text: §¶In the year that King Uzziah died, I saw the Lord, high and exalted, seated on a throne; and the train of his robe filled the temple.

17772.text: Above him were seraphim, each with six wings: With two wings they covered their faces, with two they covered their feet, and with two they were flying.

17773.text: And they were calling to one another:¶▼“Holy, holy, holy is the Lord Almighty;/_the whole earth is full of his glory.”

17774.text: ¶At the sound of their voices the doorposts and thresholds shook and the temple was filled with smoke.

17775.text: ¶“Woe to me!” I cried. “I am ruined! For I am a man of unclean lips, and I live among a people of unclean lips, and my eyes have seen the King, the Lord Almighty.”

17776.text: ¶Then one of the seraphim flew to me with a live coal in his hand, which he had taken with tongs from the altar.

17777.text: With it he touched my mouth and said, “See, this has touched your lips; your guilt is taken away and your sin atoned for.”

17778.text: ¶Then I heard the voice of the Lord saying, “Whom shall I send? And who will go for us?”¶And I said, “Here am I. Send me!”

17779.text: ¶He said, “Go and tell this people:¶▼“‘Be ever hearing, but never understanding;/_be ever seeing, but never perceiving.’

17780.text: /Make the heart of this people calloused;/_make their ears dull/_and close their eyes./Otherwise they might see with their eyes,/_hear with their ears,/_understand with their hearts,/and turn and be healed.”

17781.text: ¶Then I said, “For how long, Lord?”¶And he answered:¶▼“Until the cities lie ruined/_and without inhabitant,/until the houses are left deserted/_and the fields ruined and ravaged,

17782.text: /until the Lord has sent everyone far away/_and the land is utterly forsaken.

17783.text: /And though a tenth remains in the land,/_it will again be laid waste./But as the terebinth and oak/_leave stumps when they are cut down,/_so the holy seed will be the stump in the land.”

17784.text: §¶When Ahaz son of Jotham, the son of Uzziah, was king of Judah, King Rezin of Aram and Pekah son of Remaliah king of Israel marched up to fight against Jerusalem, but they could not overpower it.

17785.text: ¶Now the house of David was told, “Aram has allied itself with Ephraim”; so the hearts of Ahaz and his people were shaken, as the trees of the forest are shaken by the wind.

17786.text: ¶Then the Lord said to Isaiah, “Go out, you and your son Shear‐Jashub, to meet Ahaz at the end of the aqueduct of the Upper Pool, on the road to the Launderer’s Field.

17787.text: Say to him, ‘Be careful, keep calm and don’t be afraid. Do not lose heart because of these two smoldering stubs of firewood—because of the fierce anger of Rezin and Aram and of the son of Remaliah.

17788.text: Aram, Ephraim and Remaliah’s son have plotted your ruin, saying,

17789.text: “Let us invade Judah; let us tear it apart and divide it among ourselves, and make the son of Tabeel king over it.”

17790.text: Yet this is what the Sovereign Lord says:¶▼“‘It will not take place,/_it will not happen,

17791.text: /for the head of Aram is Damascus,/_and the head of Damascus is only Rezin./Within sixty‐five years/_Ephraim will be too shattered to be a people.

17792.text: /The head of Ephraim is Samaria,/_and the head of Samaria is only Remaliah’s son./If you do not stand firm in your faith,/_you will not stand at all.’”

17794.text: “Ask the Lord your God for a sign, whether in the deepest depths or in the highest heights.”

17795.text: ¶But Ahaz said, “I will not ask; I will not put the Lord to the test.”

17796.text: ¶Then Isaiah said, “Hear now, you house of David! Is it not enough to try the patience of humans? Will you try the patience of my God also?

17797.text: Therefore the Lord himself will give you a sign: The virgin will conceive and give birth to a son, and will call him Immanuel.

17798.text: He will be eating curds and honey when he knows enough to reject the wrong and choose the right,

17799.text: for before the boy knows enough to reject the wrong and choose the right, the land of the two kings you dread will be laid waste.

17800.text: The Lord will bring on you and on your people and on the house of your father a time unlike any since Ephraim broke away from Judah—he will bring the king of Assyria.”

17801.text: §¶In that day the Lord will whistle for flies from the Nile delta in Egypt and for bees from the land of Assyria.

17802.text: They will all come and settle in the steep ravines and in the crevices in the rocks, on all the thornbushes and at all the water holes.

17803.text: In that day the Lord will use a razor hired from beyond the Euphrates River—the king of Assyria—to shave your head and private parts, and to cut off your beard also.

17804.text: In that day, a person will keep alive a young cow and two goats.

17805.text: And because of the abundance of the milk they give, there will be curds to eat. All who remain in the land will eat curds and honey.

17806.text: In that day, in every place where there were a thousand vines worth a thousand silver shekels, there will be only briers and thorns.

17807.text: Hunters will go there with bow and arrow, for the land will be covered with briers and thorns.

17808.text: As for all the hills once cultivated by the hoe, you will no longer go there for fear of the briers and thorns; they will become places where cattle are turned loose and where sheep run.

17809.text: §¶The Lord said to me, “Take a large scroll and write on it with an ordinary pen: Maher‐Shalal‐Hash‐Baz.”

17810.text: So I called in Uriah the priest and Zechariah son of Jeberekiah as reliable witnesses for me.

17811.text: Then I made love to the prophetess, and she conceived and gave birth to a son. And the Lord said to me, “Name him Maher‐Shalal‐Hash‐Baz.

17812.text: For before the boy knows how to say ‘My father’ or ‘My mother,’ the wealth of Damascus and the plunder of Samaria will be carried off by the king of Assyria.”

17814.text: ¶“Because this people has rejected/_the gently flowing waters of Shiloah/and rejoices over Rezin/_and the son of Remaliah,

17815.text: /therefore the Lord is about to bring against them/_the mighty floodwaters of the Euphrates—/_the king of Assyria with all his pomp./It will overflow all its channels,/_run over all its banks

17816.text: /and sweep on into Judah, swirling over it,/_passing through it and reaching up to the neck./Its outspread wings will cover the breadth of your land,/_Immanuel!”

17817.text: ¶Raise the war cry, you nations, and be shattered!/_Listen, all you distant lands./Prepare for battle, and be shattered!/_Prepare for battle, and be shattered!

17818.text: /Devise your strategy, but it will be thwarted;/_propose your plan, but it will not stand,/_for God is with us.

17819.text: ¶This is what the Lord says to me with his strong hand upon me, warning me not to follow the way of this people:

17820.text: ¶“Do not call conspiracy/_everything this people calls a conspiracy;/do not fear what they fear,/_and do not dread it.

17821.text: /The Lord Almighty is the one you are to regard as holy,/_he is the one you are to fear,/_he is the one you are to dread.

17822.text: /He will be a holy place;/_for both Israel and Judah he will be/a stone that causes people to stumble/_and a rock that makes them fall./And for the people of Jerusalem he will be/_a trap and a snare.

17823.text: /Many of them will stumble;/_they will fall and be broken,/_they will be snared and captured.”

17824.text: ¶Bind up this testimony of warning/_and seal up God’s instruction among my disciples.

17825.text: /I will wait for the Lord,/_who is hiding his face from the descendants of Jacob./I will put my trust in him.

17826.text: ¶Here am I, and the children the Lord has given me. We are signs and symbols in Israel from the Lord Almighty, who dwells on Mount Zion.

17827.text: §¶When someone tells you to consult mediums and spiritists, who whisper and mutter, should not a people inquire of their God? Why consult the dead on behalf of the living?

17828.text: Consult God’s instruction and the testimony of warning. If anyone does not speak according to this word, they have no light of dawn.

17829.text: Distressed and hungry, they will roam through the land; when they are famished, they will become enraged and, looking upward, will curse their king and their God.

17830.text: Then they will look toward the earth and see only distress and darkness and fearful gloom, and they will be thrust into utter darkness.

17831.text: ¶Nevertheless, there will be no more gloom for those who were in distress. In the past he humbled the land of Zebulun and the land of Naphtali, but in the future he will honor Galilee of the nations, by the Way of the Sea, beyond the Jordan—

17832.text: ¶The people walking in darkness/_have seen a great light;/on those living in the land of deep darkness/_a light has dawned.

17833.text: /You have enlarged the nation/_and increased their joy;/they rejoice before you/_as people rejoice at the harvest,/as warriors rejoice/_when dividing the plunder.

17834.text: /For as in the day of Midian’s defeat,/_you have shattered/the yoke that burdens them,/_the bar across their shoulders,/_the rod of their oppressor.

17835.text: /Every warrior’s boot used in battle/_and every garment rolled in blood/will be destined for burning,/_will be fuel for the fire.

17836.text: /For to us a child is born,/_to us a son is given,/_and the government will be on his shoulders./And he will be called/_Wonderful Counselor, Mighty God,/_Everlasting Father, Prince of Peace.

17837.text: /Of the greatness of his government and peace/_there will be no end./He will reign on David’s throne/_and over his kingdom,/establishing and upholding it/_with justice and righteousness/_from that time on and forever./The zeal of the Lord Almighty/_will accomplish this.

17838.text: §¶The Lord has sent a message against Jacob;/_it will fall on Israel.

17839.text: /All the people will know it—/_Ephraim and the inhabitants of Samaria—/who say with pride/_and arrogance of heart,

17840.text: /“The bricks have fallen down,/_but we will rebuild with dressed stone;/the fig trees have been felled,/_but we will replace them with cedars.”

17841.text: /But the Lord has strengthened Rezin’s foes against them/_and has spurred their enemies on.

17842.text: /Arameans from the east and Philistines from the west/_have devoured Israel with open mouth.¶Yet for all this, his anger is not turned away,/_his hand is still upraised.

17843.text: ¶But the people have not returned to him who struck them,/_nor have they sought the Lord Almighty.

17844.text: /So the Lord will cut off from Israel both head and tail,/_both palm branch and reed in a single day;

17845.text: /the elders and dignitaries are the head,/_the prophets who teach lies are the tail.

17846.text: /Those who guide this people mislead them,/_and those who are guided are led astray.

17847.text: /Therefore the Lord will take no pleasure in the young men,/_nor will he pity the fatherless and widows,/for everyone is ungodly and wicked,/_every mouth speaks folly.¶Yet for all this, his anger is not turned away,/_his hand is still upraised.

17848.text: ¶Surely wickedness burns like a fire;/_it consumes briers and thorns,/it sets the forest thickets ablaze,/_so that it rolls upward in a column of smoke.

17849.text: /By the wrath of the Lord Almighty/_the land will be scorched/and the people will be fuel for the fire;/_they will not spare one another.

17850.text: /On the right they will devour,/_but still be hungry;/on the left they will eat,/_but not be satisfied./Each will feed on the flesh of their own offspring:

17851.text: /_Manasseh will feed on Ephraim, and Ephraim on Manasseh;/_together they will turn against Judah.¶Yet for all this, his anger is not turned away,/_his hand is still upraised.

17852.text: ¶Woe to those who make unjust laws,/_to those who issue oppressive decrees,

17853.text: /to deprive the poor of their rights/_and withhold justice from the oppressed of my people,/making widows their prey/_and robbing the fatherless.

17854.text: /What will you do on the day of reckoning,/_when disaster comes from afar?/To whom will you run for help?/_Where will you leave your riches?

17855.text: /Nothing will remain but to cringe among the captives/_or fall among the slain.¶Yet for all this, his anger is not turned away,/_his hand is still upraised.

17856.text: §¶“Woe to the Assyrian, the rod of my anger,/_in whose hand is the club of my wrath!

17857.text: /I send him against a godless nation,/_I dispatch him against a people who anger me,/to seize loot and snatch plunder,/_and to trample them down like mud in the streets.

17858.text: /But this is not what he intends,/_this is not what he has in mind;/his purpose is to destroy,/_to put an end to many nations.

17859.text: /‘Are not my commanders all kings?’ he says.

17860.text: /_‘Has not Kalno fared like Carchemish?/Is not Hamath like Arpad,/_and Samaria like Damascus?

17861.text: /As my hand seized the kingdoms of the idols,/_kingdoms whose images excelled those of Jerusalem and Samaria—

17862.text: /shall I not deal with Jerusalem and her images/_as I dealt with Samaria and her idols?’”

17863.text: ¶When the Lord has finished all his work against Mount Zion and Jerusalem, he will say, “I will punish the king of Assyria for the willful pride of his heart and the haughty look in his eyes.

17864.text: For he says:¶▼“‘By the strength of my hand I have done this,/_and by my wisdom, because I have understanding./I removed the boundaries of nations,/_I plundered their treasures;/_like a mighty one I subdued their kings.

17865.text: /As one reaches into a nest,/_so my hand reached for the wealth of the nations;/as people gather abandoned eggs,/_so I gathered all the countries;/not one flapped a wing,/_or opened its mouth to chirp.’”

17866.text: ¶Does the ax raise itself above the person who swings it,/_or the saw boast against the one who uses it?/As if a rod were to wield the person who lifts it up,/_or a club brandish the one who is not wood!

17867.text: /Therefore, the Lord, the Lord Almighty,/_will send a wasting disease upon his sturdy warriors;/under his pomp a fire will be kindled/_like a blazing flame.

17868.text: /The Light of Israel will become a fire,/_their Holy One a flame;/in a single day it will burn and consume/_his thorns and his briers.

17869.text: /The splendor of his forests and fertile fields/_it will completely destroy,/_as when a sick person wastes away.

17870.text: /And the remaining trees of his forests will be so few/_that a child could write them down.

17871.text: §¶In that day the remnant of Israel,/_the survivors of Jacob,/will no longer rely on him/_who struck them down/but will truly rely on the Lord,/_the Holy One of Israel.

17872.text: /A remnant will return, a remnant of Jacob/_will return to the Mighty God.

17873.text: /Though your people be like the sand by the sea, Israel,/_only a remnant will return./Destruction has been decreed,/_overwhelming and righteous.

17874.text: /The Lord, the Lord Almighty, will carry out/_the destruction decreed upon the whole land.

17875.text: ¶Therefore this is what the Lord, the Lord Almighty, says:¶▼“My people who live in Zion,/_do not be afraid of the Assyrians,/who beat you with a rod/_and lift up a club against you, as Egypt did.

17876.text: /Very soon my anger against you will end/_and my wrath will be directed to their destruction.”

17877.text: ¶The Lord Almighty will lash them with a whip,/_as when he struck down Midian at the rock of Oreb;/and he will raise his staff over the waters,/_as he did in Egypt.

17878.text: /In that day their burden will be lifted from your shoulders,/_their yoke from your neck;/the yoke will be broken/_because you have grown so fat.

17879.text: ¶They enter Aiath;/_they pass through Migron;/_they store supplies at Mikmash.

17880.text: /They go over the pass, and say,/_“We will camp overnight at Geba.”/Ramah trembles;/_Gibeah of Saul flees.

17882.text: /Madmenah is in flight;/_the people of Gebim take cover.

17883.text: /This day they will halt at Nob;/_they will shake their fist/at the mount of Daughter Zion,/_at the hill of Jerusalem.

17884.text: ¶See, the Lord, the Lord Almighty,/_will lop off the boughs with great power./The lofty trees will be felled,/_the tall ones will be brought low.

17885.text: /He will cut down the forest thickets with an ax;/_Lebanon will fall before the Mighty One.

17886.text: §¶A shoot will come up from the stump of Jesse;/_from his roots a Branch will bear fruit.

17887.text: /The Spirit of the Lord will rest on him—/_the Spirit of wisdom and of understanding,/_the Spirit of counsel and of might,/_the Spirit of the knowledge and fear of the Lord—

17888.text: /and he will delight in the fear of the Lord.¶He will not judge by what he sees with his eyes,/_or decide by what he hears with his ears;

17889.text: /but with righteousness he will judge the needy,/_with justice he will give decisions for the poor of the earth./He will strike the earth with the rod of his mouth;/_with the breath of his lips he will slay the wicked.

17890.text: /Righteousness will be his belt/_and faithfulness the sash around his waist.

17891.text: ¶The wolf will live with the lamb,/_the leopard will lie down with the goat,/the calf and the lion and the yearling together;/_and a little child will lead them.

17892.text: /The cow will feed with the bear,/_their young will lie down together,/_and the lion will eat straw like the ox.

17893.text: /The infant will play near the cobra’s den,/_and the young child will put its hand into the viper’s nest.

17894.text: /They will neither harm nor destroy/_on all my holy mountain,/for the earth will be filled with the knowledge of the Lord/_as the waters cover the sea.

17895.text: ¶In that day the Root of Jesse will stand as a banner for the peoples; the nations will rally to him, and his resting place will be glorious.

17896.text: In that day the Lord will reach out his hand a second time to reclaim the surviving remnant of his people from Assyria, from Lower Egypt, from Upper Egypt, from Cush, from Elam, from Babylonia, from Hamath and from the islands of the Mediterranean.

17897.text: ¶He will raise a banner for the nations/_and gather the exiles of Israel;/he will assemble the scattered people of Judah/_from the four quarters of the earth.

17898.text: /Ephraim’s jealousy will vanish,/_and Judah’s enemies will be destroyed;/Ephraim will not be jealous of Judah,/_nor Judah hostile toward Ephraim.

17899.text: /They will swoop down on the slopes of Philistia to the west;/_together they will plunder the people to the east./They will subdue Edom and Moab,/_and the Ammonites will be subject to them.

17900.text: /The Lord will dry up/_the gulf of the Egyptian sea;/with a scorching wind he will sweep his hand/_over the Euphrates River./He will break it up into seven streams/_so that anyone can cross over in sandals.

17901.text: /There will be a highway for the remnant of his people/_that is left from Assyria,/as there was for Israel/_when they came up from Egypt.

17902.text: §¶In that day you will say:¶▼“I will praise you, Lord./_Although you were angry with me,/your anger has turned away/_and you have comforted me.

17903.text: /Surely God is my salvation;/_I will trust and not be afraid./The Lord, the Lord himself, is my strength and my defense;/_he has become my salvation.”

17904.text: /With joy you will draw water/_from the wells of salvation.

17905.text: ¶In that day you will say:¶▼“Give praise to the Lord, proclaim his name;/_make known among the nations what he has done,/_and proclaim that his name is exalted.

17906.text: /Sing to the Lord, for he has done glorious things;/_let this be known to all the world.

17907.text: /Shout aloud and sing for joy, people of Zion,/_for great is the Holy One of Israel among you.”

17908.text: §¶A prophecy against Babylon that Isaiah son of Amoz saw:

17909.text: ¶Raise a banner on a bare hilltop,/_shout to them;/beckon to them/_to enter the gates of the nobles.

17910.text: /I have commanded those I prepared for battle;/_I have summoned my warriors to carry out my wrath—/_those who rejoice in my triumph.

17911.text: ¶Listen, a noise on the mountains,/_like that of a great multitude!/Listen, an uproar among the kingdoms,/_like nations massing together!/The Lord Almighty is mustering/_an army for war.

17912.text: /They come from faraway lands,/_from the ends of the heavens—/the Lord and the weapons of his wrath—/_to destroy the whole country.

17913.text: ¶Wail, for the day of the Lord is near;/_it will come like destruction from the Almighty.

17914.text: /Because of this, all hands will go limp,/_every heart will melt with fear.

17915.text: /Terror will seize them,/_pain and anguish will grip them;/_they will writhe like a woman in labor./They will look aghast at each other,/_their faces aflame.

17916.text: ¶See, the day of the Lord is coming/_—a cruel day, with wrath and fierce anger—/to make the land desolate/_and destroy the sinners within it.

17917.text: /The stars of heaven and their constellations/_will not show their light./The rising sun will be darkened/_and the moon will not give its light.

17918.text: /I will punish the world for its evil,/_the wicked for their sins./I will put an end to the arrogance of the haughty/_and will humble the pride of the ruthless.

17919.text: /I will make people scarcer than pure gold,/_more rare than the gold of Ophir.

17920.text: /Therefore I will make the heavens tremble;/_and the earth will shake from its place/at the wrath of the Lord Almighty,/_in the day of his burning anger.

17921.text: ¶Like a hunted gazelle,/_like sheep without a shepherd,/they will all return to their own people,/_they will flee to their native land.

17922.text: /Whoever is captured will be thrust through;/_all who are caught will fall by the sword.

17923.text: /Their infants will be dashed to pieces before their eyes;/_their houses will be looted and their wives violated.

17924.text: ¶See, I will stir up against them the Medes,/_who do not care for silver/_and have no delight in gold.

17925.text: /Their bows will strike down the young men;/_they will have no mercy on infants,/_nor will they look with compassion on children.

17926.text: /Babylon, the jewel of kingdoms,/_the pride and glory of the Babylonians,/will be overthrown by God/_like Sodom and Gomorrah.

17927.text: /She will never be inhabited/_or lived in through all generations;/there no nomads will pitch their tents,/_there no shepherds will rest their flocks.

17928.text: /But desert creatures will lie there,/_jackals will fill her houses;/there the owls will dwell,/_and there the wild goats will leap about.

17929.text: /Hyenas will inhabit her strongholds,/_jackals her luxurious palaces./Her time is at hand,/_and her days will not be prolonged.

17930.text: ¶The Lord will have compassion on Jacob;/_once again he will choose Israel/_and will settle them in their own land./Foreigners will join them/_and unite with the descendants of Jacob.

17931.text: /Nations will take them/_and bring them to their own place./And Israel will take possession of the nations/_and make them male and female servants in the Lord’s land./They will make captives of their captors/_and rule over their oppressors.

17932.text: ¶On the day the Lord gives you relief from your suffering and turmoil and from the harsh labor forced on you,

17933.text: you will take up this taunt against the king of Babylon:¶▼How the oppressor has come to an end!/_How his fury has ended!

17934.text: /The Lord has broken the rod of the wicked,/_the scepter of the rulers,

17935.text: /which in anger struck down peoples/_with unceasing blows,/and in fury subdued nations/_with relentless aggression.

17936.text: /All the lands are at rest and at peace;/_they break into singing.

17937.text: /Even the junipers and the cedars of Lebanon/_gloat over you and say,/“Now that you have been laid low,/_no one comes to cut us down.”

17938.text: ¶The realm of the dead below is all astir/_to meet you at your coming;/it rouses the spirits of the departed to greet you—/_all those who were leaders in the world;/it makes them rise from their thrones—/_all those who were kings over the nations.

17939.text: /They will all respond,/_they will say to you,/“You also have become weak, as we are;/_you have become like us.”

17940.text: /All your pomp has been brought down to the grave,/_along with the noise of your harps;/maggots are spread out beneath you/_and worms cover you.

17941.text: ¶How you have fallen from heaven,/_morning star, son of the dawn!/You have been cast down to the earth,/_you who once laid low the nations!

17942.text: /You said in your heart,/_“I will ascend to the heavens;/I will raise my throne/_above the stars of God;/I will sit enthroned on the mount of assembly,/_on the utmost heights of Mount Zaphon.

17943.text: /I will ascend above the tops of the clouds;/_I will make myself like the Most High.”

17944.text: /But you are brought down to the realm of the dead,/_to the depths of the pit.

17945.text: ¶Those who see you stare at you,/_they ponder your fate:/“Is this the man who shook the earth/_and made kingdoms tremble,

17946.text: /the man who made the world a wilderness,/_who overthrew its cities/_and would not let his captives go home?”

17947.text: ¶All the kings of the nations lie in state,/_each in his own tomb.

17948.text: /But you are cast out of your tomb/_like a rejected branch;/you are covered with the slain,/_with those pierced by the sword,/_those who descend to the stones of the pit./Like a corpse trampled underfoot,

17949.text: /_you will not join them in burial,/for you have destroyed your land/_and killed your people.¶Let the offspring of the wicked/_never be mentioned again.

17950.text: /Prepare a place to slaughter his children/_for the sins of their ancestors;/they are not to rise to inherit the land/_and cover the earth with their cities.

17951.text: ¶“I will rise up against them,”/_declares the Lord Almighty./“I will wipe out Babylon’s name and survivors,/_her offspring and descendants,”/declares the Lord.

17952.text: /“I will turn her into a place for owls/_and into swampland;/I will sweep her with the broom of destruction,”/_declares the Lord Almighty.

17953.text: ¶The Lord Almighty has sworn,¶▼“Surely, as I have planned, so it will be,/_and as I have purposed, so it will happen.

17954.text: /I will crush the Assyrian in my land;/_on my mountains I will trample him down./His yoke will be taken from my people,/_and his burden removed from their shoulders.”

17955.text: ¶This is the plan determined for the whole world;/_this is the hand stretched out over all nations.

17956.text: /For the Lord Almighty has purposed, and who can thwart him?/_His hand is stretched out, and who can turn it back?

17957.text: §¶This prophecy came in the year King Ahaz died:

17958.text: ¶Do not rejoice, all you Philistines,/_that the rod that struck you is broken;/from the root of that snake will spring up a viper,/_its fruit will be a darting, venomous serpent.

17959.text: /The poorest of the poor will find pasture,/_and the needy will lie down in safety./But your root I will destroy by famine;/_it will slay your survivors.

17960.text: ¶Wail, you gate! Howl, you city!/_Melt away, all you Philistines!/A cloud of smoke comes from the north,/_and there is not a straggler in its ranks.

17961.text: /What answer shall be given/_to the envoys of that nation?/“The Lord has established Zion,/_and in her his afflicted people will find refuge.”

17962.text: §¶A prophecy against Moab:¶▼Ar in Moab is ruined,/_destroyed in a night!/Kir in Moab is ruined,/_destroyed in a night!

17963.text: /Dibon goes up to its temple,/_to its high places to weep;/_Moab wails over Nebo and Medeba./Every head is shaved/_and every beard cut off.

17964.text: /In the streets they wear sackcloth;/_on the roofs and in the public squares/they all wail,/_prostrate with weeping.

17965.text: /Heshbon and Elealeh cry out,/_their voices are heard all the way to Jahaz./Therefore the armed men of Moab cry out,/_and their hearts are faint.

17966.text: ¶My heart cries out over Moab;/_her fugitives flee as far as Zoar,/_as far as Eglath Shelishiyah./They go up the hill to Luhith,/_weeping as they go;/on the road to Horonaim/_they lament their destruction.

17967.text: /The waters of Nimrim are dried up/_and the grass is withered;/the vegetation is gone/_and nothing green is left.

17968.text: /So the wealth they have acquired and stored up/_they carry away over the Ravine of the Poplars.

17969.text: /Their outcry echoes along the border of Moab;/_their wailing reaches as far as Eglaim,/_their lamentation as far as Beer Elim.

17970.text: /The waters of Dimon are full of blood,/_but I will bring still more upon Dimon—/a lion upon the fugitives of Moab/_and upon those who remain in the land.

17971.text: ¶Send lambs as tribute/_to the ruler of the land,/from Sela, across the desert,/_to the mount of Daughter Zion.

17972.text: /Like fluttering birds/_pushed from the nest,/so are the women of Moab/_at the fords of the Arnon.

17973.text: ¶“Make up your mind,” Moab says./_“Render a decision./Make your shadow like night—/_at high noon./Hide the fugitives,/_do not betray the refugees.

17974.text: /Let the Moabite fugitives stay with you;/_be their shelter from the destroyer.”¶The oppressor will come to an end,/_and destruction will cease;/_the aggressor will vanish from the land.

17975.text: /In love a throne will be established;/_in faithfulness a man will sit on it—/_one from the house of David—/one who in judging seeks justice/_and speeds the cause of righteousness.

17976.text: ¶We have heard of Moab’s pride—/_how great is her arrogance!—/of her conceit, her pride and her insolence;/_but her boasts are empty.

17977.text: /Therefore the Moabites wail,/_they wail together for Moab./Lament and grieve/_for the raisin cakes of Kir Hareseth.

17978.text: /The fields of Heshbon wither,/_the vines of Sibmah also./The rulers of the nations/_have trampled down the choicest vines,/which once reached Jazer/_and spread toward the desert./Their shoots spread out/_and went as far as the sea.

17979.text: /So I weep, as Jazer weeps,/_for the vines of Sibmah./Heshbon and Elealeh,/_I drench you with tears!/The shouts of joy over your ripened fruit/_and over your harvests have been stilled.

17980.text: /Joy and gladness are taken away from the orchards;/_no one sings or shouts in the vineyards;/no one treads out wine at the presses,/_for I have put an end to the shouting.

17981.text: /My heart laments for Moab like a harp,/_my inmost being for Kir Hareseth.

17982.text: /When Moab appears at her high place,/_she only wears herself out;/when she goes to her shrine to pray,/_it is to no avail.

17983.text: ¶This is the word the Lord has already spoken concerning Moab.

17984.text: But now the Lord says: “Within three years, as a servant bound by contract would count them, Moab’s splendor and all her many people will be despised, and her survivors will be very few and feeble.”

17985.text: §¶A prophecy against Damascus:¶▼“See, Damascus will no longer be a city/_but will become a heap of ruins.

17986.text: /The cities of Aroer will be deserted/_and left to flocks, which will lie down,/_with no one to make them afraid.

17987.text: /The fortified city will disappear from Ephraim,/_and royal power from Damascus;/the remnant of Aram will be/_like the glory of the Israelites,”/declares the Lord Almighty.

17988.text: ¶“In that day the glory of Jacob will fade;/_the fat of his body will waste away.

17989.text: /It will be as when reapers harvest the standing grain,/_gathering the grain in their arms—/as when someone gleans heads of grain/_in the Valley of Rephaim.

17990.text: /Yet some gleanings will remain,/_as when an olive tree is beaten,/leaving two or three olives on the topmost branches,/_four or five on the fruitful boughs,”/declares the Lord, the God of Israel.

17991.text: ¶In that day people will look to their Maker/_and turn their eyes to the Holy One of Israel.

17992.text: /They will not look to the altars,/_the work of their hands,/and they will have no regard for the Asherah poles/_and the incense altars their fingers have made.

17993.text: ¶In that day their strong cities, which they left because of the Israelites, will be like places abandoned to thickets and undergrowth. And all will be desolation.

17994.text: ¶You have forgotten God your Savior;/_you have not remembered the Rock, your fortress./Therefore, though you set out the finest plants/_and plant imported vines,

17995.text: /though on the day you set them out, you make them grow,/_and on the morning when you plant them, you bring them to bud,/yet the harvest will be as nothing/_in the day of disease and incurable pain.

17996.text: ¶Woe to the many nations that rage—/_they rage like the raging sea!/Woe to the peoples who roar—/_they roar like the roaring of great waters!

17997.text: /Although the peoples roar like the roar of surging waters,/_when he rebukes them they flee far away,/driven before the wind like chaff on the hills,/_like tumbleweed before a gale.

17998.text: /In the evening, sudden terror!/_Before the morning, they are gone!/This is the portion of those who loot us,/_the lot of those who plunder us.

17999.text: §¶Woe to the land of whirring wings/_along the rivers of Cush,

18000.text: /which sends envoys by sea/_in papyrus boats over the water.¶Go, swift messengers,/to a people tall and smooth‐skinned,/_to a people feared far and wide,/an aggressive nation of strange speech,/_whose land is divided by rivers.

18001.text: ¶All you people of the world,/_you who live on the earth,/when a banner is raised on the mountains,/_you will see it,/and when a trumpet sounds,/_you will hear it.

18002.text: /This is what the Lord says to me:/_“I will remain quiet and will look on from my dwelling place,/like shimmering heat in the sunshine,/_like a cloud of dew in the heat of harvest.”

18003.text: /For, before the harvest, when the blossom is gone/_and the flower becomes a ripening grape,/he will cut off the shoots with pruning knives,/_and cut down and take away the spreading branches.

18004.text: /They will all be left to the mountain birds of prey/_and to the wild animals;/the birds will feed on them all summer,/_the wild animals all winter.

18005.text: ¶At that time gifts will be brought to the Lord Almighty¶▼from a people tall and smooth‐skinned,/_from a people feared far and wide,/an aggressive nation of strange speech,/_whose land is divided by rivers—¶►the gifts will be brought to Mount Zion, the place of the Name of the Lord Almighty.

18006.text: §¶A prophecy against Egypt:¶▼See, the Lord rides on a swift cloud/_and is coming to Egypt./The idols of Egypt tremble before him,/_and the hearts of the Egyptians melt with fear.

18007.text: ¶“I will stir up Egyptian against Egyptian—/_brother will fight against brother,/_neighbor against neighbor,/_city against city,/_kingdom against kingdom.

18008.text: /The Egyptians will lose heart,/_and I will bring their plans to nothing;/they will consult the idols and the spirits of the dead,/_the mediums and the spiritists.

18009.text: /I will hand the Egyptians over/_to the power of a cruel master,/and a fierce king will rule over them,”/_declares the Lord, the Lord Almighty.

18010.text: ¶The waters of the river will dry up,/_and the riverbed will be parched and dry.

18011.text: /The canals will stink;/_the streams of Egypt will dwindle and dry up./The reeds and rushes will wither,

18012.text: /_also the plants along the Nile,/_at the mouth of the river./Every sown field along the Nile/_will become parched, will blow away and be no more.

18013.text: /The fishermen will groan and lament,/_all who cast hooks into the Nile;/those who throw nets on the water/_will pine away.

18014.text: /Those who work with combed flax will despair,/_the weavers of fine linen will lose hope.

18015.text: /The workers in cloth will be dejected,/_and all the wage earners will be sick at heart.

18016.text: ¶The officials of Zoan are nothing but fools;/_the wise counselors of Pharaoh give senseless advice./How can you say to Pharaoh,/_“I am one of the wise men,/_a disciple of the ancient kings”?

18017.text: ¶Where are your wise men now?/_Let them show you and make known/what the Lord Almighty/_has planned against Egypt.

18018.text: /The officials of Zoan have become fools,/_the leaders of Memphis are deceived;/the cornerstones of her peoples/_have led Egypt astray.

18019.text: /The Lord has poured into them/_a spirit of dizziness;/they make Egypt stagger in all that she does,/_as a drunkard staggers around in his vomit.

18020.text: /There is nothing Egypt can do—/_head or tail, palm branch or reed.

18021.text: ¶In that day the Egyptians will become weaklings. They will shudder with fear at the uplifted hand that the Lord Almighty raises against them.

18022.text: And the land of Judah will bring terror to the Egyptians; everyone to whom Judah is mentioned will be terrified, because of what the Lord Almighty is planning against them.

18023.text: ¶In that day five cities in Egypt will speak the language of Canaan and swear allegiance to the Lord Almighty. One of them will be called the City of the Sun.

18024.text: ¶In that day there will be an altar to the Lord in the heart of Egypt, and a monument to the Lord at its border.

18025.text: It will be a sign and witness to the Lord Almighty in the land of Egypt. When they cry out to the Lord because of their oppressors, he will send them a savior and defender, and he will rescue them.

18026.text: So the Lord will make himself known to the Egyptians, and in that day they will acknowledge the Lord. They will worship with sacrifices and grain offerings; they will make vows to the Lord and keep them.

18027.text: The Lord will strike Egypt with a plague; he will strike them and heal them. They will turn to the Lord, and he will respond to their pleas and heal them.

18028.text: ¶In that day there will be a highway from Egypt to Assyria. The Assyrians will go to Egypt and the Egyptians to Assyria. The Egyptians and Assyrians will worship together.

18029.text: In that day Israel will be the third, along with Egypt and Assyria, a blessing on the earth.

18030.text: The Lord Almighty will bless them, saying, “Blessed be Egypt my people, Assyria my handiwork, and Israel my inheritance.”

18031.text: §¶In the year that the supreme commander, sent by Sargon king of Assyria, came to Ashdod and attacked and captured it—

18032.text: at that time the Lord spoke through Isaiah son of Amoz. He said to him, “Take off the sackcloth from your body and the sandals from your feet.” And he did so, going around stripped and barefoot.

18033.text: ¶Then the Lord said, “Just as my servant Isaiah has gone stripped and barefoot for three years, as a sign and portent against Egypt and Cush,

18034.text: so the king of Assyria will lead away stripped and barefoot the Egyptian captives and Cushite exiles, young and old, with buttocks bared—to Egypt’s shame.

18035.text: Those who trusted in Cush and boasted in Egypt will be dismayed and put to shame.

18036.text: In that day the people who live on this coast will say, ‘See what has happened to those we relied on, those we fled to for help and deliverance from the king of Assyria! How then can we escape?’”

18037.text: §¶A prophecy against the Desert by the Sea:¶▼Like whirlwinds sweeping through the southland,/_an invader comes from the desert,/_from a land of terror.

18038.text: ¶A dire vision has been shown to me:/_The traitor betrays, the looter takes loot./Elam, attack! Media, lay siege!/_I will bring to an end all the groaning she caused.

18039.text: ¶At this my body is racked with pain,/_pangs seize me, like those of a woman in labor;/I am staggered by what I hear,/_I am bewildered by what I see.

18040.text: /My heart falters,/_fear makes me tremble;/the twilight I longed for/_has become a horror to me.

18041.text: ¶They set the tables,/_they spread the rugs,/_they eat, they drink!/Get up, you officers,/_oil the shields!

18042.text: ¶This is what the Lord says to me:¶▼“Go, post a lookout/_and have him report what he sees.

18043.text: /When he sees chariots/_with teams of horses,/riders on donkeys/_or riders on camels,/let him be alert,/_fully alert.”

18044.text: ¶And the lookout shouted,¶▼“Day after day, my lord, I stand on the watchtower;/_every night I stay at my post.

18045.text: /Look, here comes a man in a chariot/_with a team of horses./And he gives back the answer:/_‘Babylon has fallen, has fallen!/All the images of its gods/_lie shattered on the ground!’”

18046.text: ¶My people who are crushed on the threshing floor,/_I tell you what I have heard/from the Lord Almighty,/_from the God of Israel.

18047.text: §¶A prophecy against Dumah:¶▼Someone calls to me from Seir,/_“Watchman, what is left of the night?/_Watchman, what is left of the night?”

18048.text: /The watchman replies,/_“Morning is coming, but also the night./If you would ask, then ask;/_and come back yet again.”

18049.text: §¶A prophecy against Arabia:¶▼You caravans of Dedanites,/_who camp in the thickets of Arabia,

18050.text: /_bring water for the thirsty;/you who live in Tema,/_bring food for the fugitives.

18051.text: /They flee from the sword,/_from the drawn sword,/from the bent bow/_and from the heat of battle.

18052.text: ¶This is what the Lord says to me: “Within one year, as a servant bound by contract would count it, all the splendor of Kedar will come to an end.

18053.text: The survivors of the archers, the warriors of Kedar, will be few.” The Lord, the God of Israel, has spoken.

18054.text: §¶A prophecy against the Valley of Vision:¶▼What troubles you now,/_that you have all gone up on the roofs,

18055.text: /you town so full of commotion,/_you city of tumult and revelry?/Your slain were not killed by the sword,/_nor did they die in battle.

18056.text: /All your leaders have fled together;/_they have been captured without using the bow./All you who were caught were taken prisoner together,/_having fled while the enemy was still far away.

18057.text: /Therefore I said, “Turn away from me;/_let me weep bitterly./Do not try to console me/_over the destruction of my people.”

18058.text: ¶The Lord, the Lord Almighty, has a day/_of tumult and trampling and terror/_in the Valley of Vision,/a day of battering down walls/_and of crying out to the mountains.

18059.text: /Elam takes up the quiver,/_with her charioteers and horses;/_Kir uncovers the shield.

18060.text: /Your choicest valleys are full of chariots,/_and horsemen are posted at the city gates.

18061.text: ¶The Lord stripped away the defenses of Judah,/_and you looked in that day/_to the weapons in the Palace of the Forest.

18062.text: /You saw that the walls of the City of David/_were broken through in many places;/you stored up water/_in the Lower Pool.

18063.text: /You counted the buildings in Jerusalem/_and tore down houses to strengthen the wall.

18064.text: /You built a reservoir between the two walls/_for the water of the Old Pool,/but you did not look to the One who made it,/_or have regard for the One who planned it long ago.

18065.text: ¶The Lord, the Lord Almighty,/_called you on that day/to weep and to wail,/_to tear out your hair and put on sackcloth.

18066.text: /But see, there is joy and revelry,/_slaughtering of cattle and killing of sheep,/_eating of meat and drinking of wine!/“Let us eat and drink,” you say,/_“for tomorrow we die!”

18067.text: ¶The Lord Almighty has revealed this in my hearing: “Till your dying day this sin will not be atoned for,” says the Lord, the Lord Almighty.

18068.text: ¶This is what the Lord, the Lord Almighty, says:¶▼“Go, say to this steward,/_to Shebna the palace administrator:

18069.text: /What are you doing here and who gave you permission/_to cut out a grave for yourself here,/hewing your grave on the height/_and chiseling your resting place in the rock?

18070.text: ¶“Beware, the Lord is about to take firm hold of you/_and hurl you away, you mighty man.

18071.text: /He will roll you up tightly like a ball/_and throw you into a large country./There you will die/_and there the chariots you were so proud of/_will become a disgrace to your master’s house.

18072.text: /I will depose you from your office,/_and you will be ousted from your position.

18073.text: ¶“In that day I will summon my servant, Eliakim son of Hilkiah.

18074.text: I will clothe him with your robe and fasten your sash around him and hand your authority over to him. He will be a father to those who live in Jerusalem and to the people of Judah.

18075.text: I will place on his shoulder the key to the house of David; what he opens no one can shut, and what he shuts no one can open.

18076.text: I will drive him like a peg into a firm place; he will become a seat of honor for the house of his father.

18077.text: All the glory of his family will hang on him: its offspring and offshoots—all its lesser vessels, from the bowls to all the jars.

18078.text: ¶“In that day,” declares the Lord Almighty, “the peg driven into the firm place will give way; it will be sheared off and will fall, and the load hanging on it will be cut down.” The Lord has spoken.

18079.text: §¶A prophecy against Tyre:¶▼Wail, you ships of Tarshish!/_For Tyre is destroyed/_and left without house or harbor./From the land of Cyprus/_word has come to them.

18080.text: ¶Be silent, you people of the island/_and you merchants of Sidon,/_whom the seafarers have enriched.

18081.text: /On the great waters/_came the grain of the Shihor;/the harvest of the Nile was the revenue of Tyre,/_and she became the marketplace of the nations.

18082.text: ¶Be ashamed, Sidon, and you fortress of the sea,/_for the sea has spoken:/“I have neither been in labor nor given birth;/_I have neither reared sons nor brought up daughters.”

18083.text: /When word comes to Egypt,/_they will be in anguish at the report from Tyre.

18084.text: ¶Cross over to Tarshish;/_wail, you people of the island.

18085.text: /Is this your city of revelry,/_the old, old city,/whose feet have taken her/_to settle in far‐off lands?

18086.text: /Who planned this against Tyre,/_the bestower of crowns,/whose merchants are princes,/_whose traders are renowned in the earth?

18087.text: /The Lord Almighty planned it,/_to bring down her pride in all her splendor/_and to humble all who are renowned on the earth.

18088.text: ¶Till your land as they do along the Nile,/_Daughter Tarshish,/_for you no longer have a harbor.

18089.text: /The Lord has stretched out his hand over the sea/_and made its kingdoms tremble./He has given an order concerning Phoenicia/_that her fortresses be destroyed.

18090.text: /He said, “No more of your reveling,/_Virgin Daughter Sidon, now crushed!¶“Up, cross over to Cyprus;/_even there you will find no rest.”

18091.text: /Look at the land of the Babylonians,/_this people that is now of no account!/The Assyrians have made it/_a place for desert creatures;/they raised up their siege towers,/_they stripped its fortresses bare/_and turned it into a ruin.

18092.text: ¶Wail, you ships of Tarshish;/_your fortress is destroyed!

18093.text: ¶At that time Tyre will be forgotten for seventy years, the span of a king’s life. But at the end of these seventy years, it will happen to Tyre as in the song of the prostitute:

18094.text: ¶“Take up a harp, walk through the city,/_you forgotten prostitute;/play the harp well, sing many a song,/_so that you will be remembered.”

18095.text: ¶At the end of seventy years, the Lord will deal with Tyre. She will return to her lucrative prostitution and will ply her trade with all the kingdoms on the face of the earth.

18096.text: Yet her profit and her earnings will be set apart for the Lord; they will not be stored up or hoarded. Her profits will go to those who live before the Lord, for abundant food and fine clothes.

18097.text: §¶See, the Lord is going to lay waste the earth/_and devastate it;/he will ruin its face/_and scatter its inhabitants—

18098.text: /it will be the same/_for priest as for people,/_for the master as for his servant,/_for the mistress as for her servant,/_for seller as for buyer,/_for borrower as for lender,/_for debtor as for creditor.

18099.text: /The earth will be completely laid waste/_and totally plundered./The Lord has spoken this word.

18100.text: ¶The earth dries up and withers,/_the world languishes and withers,/_the heavens languish with the earth.

18101.text: /The earth is defiled by its people;/_they have disobeyed the laws,/violated the statutes/_and broken the everlasting covenant.

18102.text: /Therefore a curse consumes the earth;/_its people must bear their guilt./Therefore earth’s inhabitants are burned up,/_and very few are left.

18103.text: /The new wine dries up and the vine withers;/_all the merrymakers groan.

18104.text: /The joyful timbrels are stilled,/_the noise of the revelers has stopped,/_the joyful harp is silent.

18105.text: /No longer do they drink wine with a song;/_the beer is bitter to its drinkers.

18106.text: /The ruined city lies desolate;/_the entrance to every house is barred.

18107.text: /In the streets they cry out for wine;/_all joy turns to gloom,/_all joyful sounds are banished from the earth.

18108.text: /The city is left in ruins,/_its gate is battered to pieces.

18109.text: /So will it be on the earth/_and among the nations,/as when an olive tree is beaten,/_or as when gleanings are left after the grape harvest.

18110.text: ¶They raise their voices, they shout for joy;/_from the west they acclaim the Lord’s majesty.

18111.text: /Therefore in the east give glory to the Lord;/_exalt the name of the Lord, the God of Israel,/_in the islands of the sea.

18112.text: /From the ends of the earth we hear singing:/_“Glory to the Righteous One.”¶But I said, “I waste away, I waste away!/_Woe to me!/The treacherous betray!/_With treachery the treacherous betray!”

18113.text: /Terror and pit and snare await you,/_people of the earth.

18114.text: /Whoever flees at the sound of terror/_will fall into a pit;/whoever climbs out of the pit/_will be caught in a snare.¶The floodgates of the heavens are opened,/_the foundations of the earth shake.

18115.text: /The earth is broken up,/_the earth is split asunder,/_the earth is violently shaken.

18116.text: /The earth reels like a drunkard,/_it sways like a hut in the wind;/so heavy upon it is the guilt of its rebellion/_that it falls—never to rise again.

18117.text: ¶In that day the Lord will punish/_the powers in the heavens above/_and the kings on the earth below.

18118.text: /They will be herded together/_like prisoners bound in a dungeon;/they will be shut up in prison/_and be punished after many days.

18119.text: /The moon will be dismayed,/_the sun ashamed;/for the Lord Almighty will reign/_on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem,/_and before its elders—with great glory.

18120.text: §¶Lord, you are my God;/_I will exalt you and praise your name,/for in perfect faithfulness/_you have done wonderful things,/_things planned long ago.

18121.text: /You have made the city a heap of rubble,/_the fortified town a ruin,/the foreigners’ stronghold a city no more;/_it will never be rebuilt.

18122.text: /Therefore strong peoples will honor you;/_cities of ruthless nations will revere you.

18123.text: /You have been a refuge for the poor,/_a refuge for the needy in their distress,/a shelter from the storm/_and a shade from the heat./For the breath of the ruthless/_is like a storm driving against a wall

18124.text: /_and like the heat of the desert./You silence the uproar of foreigners;/_as heat is reduced by the shadow of a cloud,/_so the song of the ruthless is stilled.

18125.text: ¶On this mountain the Lord Almighty will prepare/_a feast of rich food for all peoples,/a banquet of aged wine—/_the best of meats and the finest of wines.

18126.text: /On this mountain he will destroy/_the shroud that enfolds all peoples,/the sheet that covers all nations;

18127.text: /_he will swallow up death forever./The Sovereign Lord will wipe away the tears/_from all faces;/he will remove his people’s disgrace/_from all the earth./The Lord has spoken.

18128.text: ¶In that day they will say,¶▼“Surely this is our God;/_we trusted in him, and he saved us./This is the Lord, we trusted in him;/_let us rejoice and be glad in his salvation.”

18129.text: ¶The hand of the Lord will rest on this mountain;/_but Moab will be trampled in their land/_as straw is trampled down in the manure.

18130.text: /They will stretch out their hands in it,/_as swimmers stretch out their hands to swim./God will bring down their pride/_despite the cleverness of their hands.

18131.text: /He will bring down your high fortified walls/_and lay them low;/he will bring them down to the ground,/_to the very dust.

18132.text: §¶In that day this song will be sung in the land of Judah:¶▼We have a strong city;/_God makes salvation/_its walls and ramparts.

18133.text: /Open the gates/_that the righteous nation may enter,/_the nation that keeps faith.

18134.text: /You will keep in perfect peace/_those whose minds are steadfast,/_because they trust in you.

18135.text: /Trust in the Lord forever,/_for the Lord, the Lord himself, is the Rock eternal.

18136.text: /He humbles those who dwell on high,/_he lays the lofty city low;/he levels it to the ground/_and casts it down to the dust.

18137.text: /Feet trample it down—/_the feet of the oppressed,/_the footsteps of the poor.

18138.text: ¶The path of the righteous is level;/_you, the Upright One, make the way of the righteous smooth.

18139.text: /Yes, Lord, walking in the way of your laws,/_we wait for you;/your name and renown/_are the desire of our hearts.

18140.text: /My soul yearns for you in the night;/_in the morning my spirit longs for you./When your judgments come upon the earth,/_the people of the world learn righteousness.

18141.text: /But when grace is shown to the wicked,/_they do not learn righteousness;/even in a land of uprightness they go on doing evil/_and do not regard the majesty of the Lord.

18142.text: /Lord, your hand is lifted high,/_but they do not see it./Let them see your zeal for your people and be put to shame;/_let the fire reserved for your enemies consume them.

18143.text: ¶Lord, you establish peace for us;/_all that we have accomplished you have done for us.

18144.text: /Lord our God, other lords besides you have ruled over us,/_but your name alone do we honor.

18145.text: /They are now dead, they live no more;/_their spirits do not rise./You punished them and brought them to ruin;/_you wiped out all memory of them.

18146.text: /You have enlarged the nation, Lord;/_you have enlarged the nation./You have gained glory for yourself;/_you have extended all the borders of the land.

18147.text: ¶Lord, they came to you in their distress;/_when you disciplined them,/_they could barely whisper a prayer.

18148.text: /As a pregnant woman about to give birth/_writhes and cries out in her pain,/_so were we in your presence, Lord.

18149.text: /We were with child, we writhed in labor,/_but we gave birth to wind./We have not brought salvation to the earth,/_and the people of the world have not come to life.

18150.text: ¶But your dead will live, Lord;/_their bodies will rise—/let those who dwell in the dust/_wake up and shout for joy—/your dew is like the dew of the morning;/_the earth will give birth to her dead.

18151.text: ¶Go, my people, enter your rooms/_and shut the doors behind you;/hide yourselves for a little while/_until his wrath has passed by.

18152.text: /See, the Lord is coming out of his dwelling/_to punish the people of the earth for their sins./The earth will disclose the blood shed on it;/_the earth will conceal its slain no longer.

18153.text: §¶In that day,¶▼the Lord will punish with his sword—/_his fierce, great and powerful sword—/Leviathan the gliding serpent,/_Leviathan the coiling serpent;/he will slay the monster of the sea.

18154.text: ¶In that day—¶▼“Sing about a fruitful vineyard:

18155.text: /_I, the Lord, watch over it;/_I water it continually./I guard it day and night/_so that no one may harm it.

18156.text: /_I am not angry./If only there were briers and thorns confronting me!/_I would march against them in battle;/_I would set them all on fire.

18157.text: /Or else let them come to me for refuge;/_let them make peace with me,/_yes, let them make peace with me.”

18158.text: ¶In days to come Jacob will take root,/_Israel will bud and blossom/_and fill all the world with fruit.

18159.text: ¶Has the Lord struck her/_as he struck down those who struck her?/Has she been killed/_as those were killed who killed her?

18160.text: /By warfare and exile you contend with her—/_with his fierce blast he drives her out,/_as on a day the east wind blows.

18161.text: /By this, then, will Jacob’s guilt be atoned for,/_and this will be the full fruit of the removal of his sin:/When he makes all the altar stones/_to be like limestone crushed to pieces,/no Asherah poles or incense altars/_will be left standing.

18162.text: /The fortified city stands desolate,/_an abandoned settlement, forsaken like the wilderness;/there the calves graze,/_there they lie down;/_they strip its branches bare.

18163.text: /When its twigs are dry, they are broken off/_and women come and make fires with them./For this is a people without understanding;/_so their Maker has no compassion on them,/_and their Creator shows them no favor.

18164.text: ¶In that day the Lord will thresh from the flowing Euphrates to the Wadi of Egypt, and you, Israel, will be gathered up one by one.

18165.text: And in that day a great trumpet will sound. Those who were perishing in Assyria and those who were exiled in Egypt will come and worship the Lord on the holy mountain in Jerusalem.

18166.text: §¶Woe to that wreath, the pride of Ephraim’s drunkards,/_to the fading flower, his glorious beauty,/set on the head of a fertile valley—/_to that city, the pride of those laid low by wine!

18167.text: /See, the Lord has one who is powerful and strong./_Like a hailstorm and a destructive wind,/like a driving rain and a flooding downpour,/_he will throw it forcefully to the ground.

18168.text: /That wreath, the pride of Ephraim’s drunkards,/_will be trampled underfoot.

18169.text: /That fading flower, his glorious beauty,/_set on the head of a fertile valley,/will be like figs ripe before harvest—/_as soon as people see them and take them in hand,/_they swallow them.

18170.text: ¶In that day the Lord Almighty/_will be a glorious crown,/a beautiful wreath/_for the remnant of his people.

18171.text: /He will be a spirit of justice/_to the one who sits in judgment,/a source of strength/_to those who turn back the battle at the gate.

18172.text: ¶And these also stagger from wine/_and reel from beer:/Priests and prophets stagger from beer/_and are befuddled with wine;/they reel from beer,/_they stagger when seeing visions,/_they stumble when rendering decisions.

18173.text: /All the tables are covered with vomit/_and there is not a spot without filth.

18174.text: ¶“Who is it he is trying to teach?/_To whom is he explaining his message?/To children weaned from their milk,/_to those just taken from the breast?

18175.text: /For it is:/_Do this, do that,/_a rule for this, a rule for that;/_a little here, a little there.”

18176.text: ¶Very well then, with foreign lips and strange tongues/_God will speak to this people,

18177.text: /to whom he said,/_“This is the resting place, let the weary rest”;/and, “This is the place of repose”—/_but they would not listen.

18178.text: /So then, the word of the Lord to them will become:/_Do this, do that,/_a rule for this, a rule for that;/_a little here, a little there—/so that as they go they will fall backward;/_they will be injured and snared and captured.

18179.text: ¶Therefore hear the word of the Lord, you scoffers/_who rule this people in Jerusalem.

18180.text: /You boast, “We have entered into a covenant with death,/_with the realm of the dead we have made an agreement./When an overwhelming scourge sweeps by,/_it cannot touch us,/for we have made a lie our refuge/_and falsehood our hiding place.”

18181.text: ¶So this is what the Sovereign Lord says:¶▼“See, I lay a stone in Zion, a tested stone,/_a precious cornerstone for a sure foundation;/the one who relies on it/_will never be stricken with panic.

18182.text: /I will make justice the measuring line/_and righteousness the plumb line;/hail will sweep away your refuge, the lie,/_and water will overflow your hiding place.

18183.text: /Your covenant with death will be annulled;/_your agreement with the realm of the dead will not stand./When the overwhelming scourge sweeps by,/_you will be beaten down by it.

18184.text: /As often as it comes it will carry you away;/_morning after morning, by day and by night,/_it will sweep through.”¶The understanding of this message/_will bring sheer terror.

18185.text: /The bed is too short to stretch out on,/_the blanket too narrow to wrap around you.

18186.text: /The Lord will rise up as he did at Mount Perazim,/_he will rouse himself as in the Valley of Gibeon—/to do his work, his strange work,/_and perform his task, his alien task.

18187.text: /Now stop your mocking,/_or your chains will become heavier;/the Lord, the Lord Almighty, has told me/_of the destruction decreed against the whole land.

18188.text: ¶Listen and hear my voice;/_pay attention and hear what I say.

18189.text: /When a farmer plows for planting, does he plow continually?/_Does he keep on breaking up and working the soil?

18190.text: /When he has leveled the surface,/_does he not sow caraway and scatter cumin?/Does he not plant wheat in its place,/_barley in its plot,/_and spelt in its field?

18191.text: /His God instructs him/_and teaches him the right way.

18192.text: ¶Caraway is not threshed with a sledge,/_nor is the wheel of a cart rolled over cumin;/caraway is beaten out with a rod,/_and cumin with a stick.

18193.text: /Grain must be ground to make bread;/_so one does not go on threshing it forever./The wheels of a threshing cart may be rolled over it,/_but one does not use horses to grind grain.

18194.text: /All this also comes from the Lord Almighty,/_whose plan is wonderful,/_whose wisdom is magnificent.

18195.text: §¶Woe to you, Ariel, Ariel,/_the city where David settled!/Add year to year/_and let your cycle of festivals go on.

18196.text: /Yet I will besiege Ariel;/_she will mourn and lament,/_she will be to me like an altar hearth.

18197.text: /I will encamp against you on all sides;/_I will encircle you with towers/_and set up my siege works against you.

18198.text: /Brought low, you will speak from the ground;/_your speech will mumble out of the dust./Your voice will come ghostlike from the earth;/_out of the dust your speech will whisper.

18199.text: ¶But your many enemies will become like fine dust,/_the ruthless hordes like blown chaff./Suddenly, in an instant,

18200.text: /_the Lord Almighty will come/with thunder and earthquake and great noise,/_with windstorm and tempest and flames of a devouring fire.

18201.text: /Then the hordes of all the nations that fight against Ariel,/_that attack her and her fortress and besiege her,/will be as it is with a dream,/_with a vision in the night—
